title: 111_s589
content: The Act titled "Global Service Fellowship Program Act of 2009" is cited as the short title. Congress finds that Secretary of State Hillary Clinton emphasizes the importance of finding common ground with other nations and investing in social development. Polling data shows that humanitarian assistance from the United States led to more favorable views in Indonesia and Pakistan. International volunteering is effective in addressing human needs and promoting mutual understanding. Current volunteer programs like the Peace Corps are crucial for promoting volunteer service and related programming. Financial limitations hinder overseas volunteering, but providing financial fellowships can help. Flexibility in volunteering duration and a global service fellowship program would further support volunteers of all backgrounds. Eligible organizations can participate as sponsoring organizations in the fellowship program. The United States Agency for International Development has initiated Volunteers for Prosperity to promote international volunteer service by skilled professionals from the United States, although the program has not been formally authorized. SEC. 3. VOLUNTEERS FOR PROSPERITY. The Office of Volunteers for Prosperity, established by the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, aims to implement the Global Service Fellowship Program, promote international volunteering opportunities, support Global Service Fellows in public diplomacy efforts, and assist in recruiting skilled professionals for volunteer assignments overseas. The Office of Volunteers for Prosperity, established by the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, aims to implement the Global Service Fellowship Program, promote international volunteering opportunities, support Global Service Fellows in public diplomacy efforts, and provide recognition for volunteers from the United States who serve internationally and the organizations sponsoring them. The Global Service Fellowship Program is established by the Office of Volunteers for Prosperity to promote international volunteering opportunities and support Global Service Fellows in public diplomacy efforts. The Global Service Fellowship Program is established by the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development to fund fellowships promoting international volunteering opportunities. Fellowships can range from 90 days to one year with funding levels up to $7,500. Coordination with sponsoring organizations is required. Fellows must coordinate with eligible volunteer sponsoring organizations registered with the Administrator to undertake volunteer opportunities. Projects are prioritized based on humanitarian and development goals, including eradicating extreme poverty and achieving universal primary education. The curr_chunk focuses on various goals related to global development and humanitarian efforts, including achieving universal primary education, promoting gender equality, reducing child mortality, providing healthcare, assisting vulnerable populations, promoting environmental sustainability, creating opportunities for youth, and combating infectious diseases like HIV/AIDS and malaria. The curr_chunk outlines the application process for fellowships under the Program, requiring applicants to submit applications to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development determines eligibility, awards fellowships, and develops criteria for Global Service Fellowships in coordination with sponsoring organizations. Applicants must be registered with qualified sponsoring organizations, such as U.S.-based NGOs that sponsor international volunteer service. Applicants for Global Service Fellowships must be registered with qualified sponsoring organizations, including volunteer service organizations, faith-based groups, universities, colleges with international service programs, and U.S.-based NGOs collaborating with local or national agencies for humanitarian and development goals. Applicants for Global Service Fellowships must have clearly defined goals, a plan for monitoring progress, and priority is given to those from households with income less than 200 percent of the poverty level. Applicants for Global Service Fellowships must have clear goals, monitor progress, and meet criteria such as community service experience, relevant skills, communication plan, and diverse geographical residence. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development notifies Members of Congress of fellowship awards to their constituents at least 2 days before informing the awardee. Fellows must submit reports within 90 days of returning from service abroad. Funds awarded under this section may be used for costs associated with Global Service Fellowships, including airfare, accommodations, transportation, fees, subsistence allowance, program materials, language and cultural training. Funds awarded under this section may not be used for tuition costs. Nondiscrimination requirements state that selection of applicants should be without regard to various factors, and sponsoring organizations should not discriminate against participants, beneficiaries, or employees. The Program prohibits discrimination based on race, religion, color, national origin, sex, age, political affiliation, sexual orientation, or disability for employees paid with assistance. There is an exception for employees of sponsoring organizations employed at the time of fund awarding, where the prohibition on religious discrimination does not apply to them. SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND REPORT. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will establish an evaluation process for the Global Service Fellowship Program. A report detailing sponsoring organizations, volunteer opportunities, and funded fellowships must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Foreign Relations by March 31, 2011. The evaluation process for the Global Service Fellowship Program includes tracking the number of funded fellowships, volunteers recruited, service locations, service effectiveness, and application numbers received and accepted. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will create regulations to implement the provisions of this Act. Authorization of appropriations is also included. SEC. 7. Authorization of appropriations for the Office of Volunteers for Prosperity and the Global Service Fellowship Program. $15,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2012. 90% of funds for Global Service Fellowships, 10% for administrative expenses. Internal Revenue Service to deposit fees as miscellaneous receipts for offset.
